model.section1Dek: Instant gratification. In the coldest, creamiest form possible.

model.seoTitle: The Easiest Ways to Make Ice Cream at Home

section2List.hed: The Secret to the Best 3-Ingredient No-Churn Ice Cream
section2List.dek: No ice cream machine? No problem.
section2List.body:
Are you the kind of cook who can whip up perfectly silky crème anglaise without heart palpitations? Do you have an insanely fancy kitchen, complete with ice cream maker? No? Bummer. No homemade ice cream for you, I guess. 

Actually, not so fast. A little thing called the internet has a solution: Fold together a combo of sweetened condensed milk and whipped cream, pour it into a loaf pan, and freeze until firm. No custard. No machines. Just cold, creamy joy.

I should know. I tried it myself. But when I ate that first batch of internet-approved no-churn ice cream, I felt something was missing. Sure, the texture was perfect pillowy. The flavor was pure dairy deliciousness. But the more scoops I ate, the more I started thinking about how I could make it even better. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce21f36a622aab4ea6419b]|||
Folding whipped cream into the DIY caramel
|||

+++

Because I can't think about cans of sweetened condensed milk without thinking of turning it into caramel. And not just any caramel: When you [simmer a still-sealed can of condensed milk](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/homemade-dulce-de-leche-395011), it, well, *caramelizes* into that especially creamy, luscious caramel known as dulce de leche. (Try it. It's sort of magic.)

Now, you *could* let that dulce de leche cool and just pour it over your ice cream... 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55cb9b376a622aab4ea638e1]|||
Don't forget the flaky salt!
|||

+++

...or you could turn it into the ice cream itself.

Think about it: If one can of sweetened condensed milk can be made into no-churn ice cream, wouldn't the same be true of dulce de leche? Turns out the answer is yes—it makes a phenomenally easy (and creamy) caramel ice cream. And what's better than caramel ice cream? Nothing. Except *salted* caramel ice cream. So I broke out the flaky sea salt and added some into the mix. (Note: Any kind of salt will make the ice cream taste better, but only flaky sea salt will add that satisfying crunch when you sprinkle it on top for serving.) 

Savor the ice cream all by itself, or top it with anything that goes with caramel: Toasted brioche cubes, sliced strawberries or peaches, or a drizzle of melted chocolate. And of course, one more pinch of crunchy salt.

[#recipe: /recipes/55ccb9254b068015388056c9]|||
No-Churn Salted Caramel Ice Cream
|||

section3List.hed: 7 New Takes on Ice Cream Sandwiches
section3List.dek: Why mess with perfection? Because you can.
section3List.promoHed: The Ultimate Ice Cream Sandwich Riffs
section3List.body:
Hand me a good old fashioned ice cream sandwich and I won't complain. I grew up on the kind made of soft, rectangular chocolate wafers that always stick to your fingers, and it never did me wrong. I even kinda liked that freezer burn flavor they sometimes had. 

But lately I've been questioning the very foundation of these childhood treats. Does ice cream even want to be sandwiched? Why is vanilla the inevitable flavor of choice? And what's with those weird, soft, rectangular cookies?

Natasha Case, co-founder of [Coolhaus](https://eatcoolhaus.com/), an L.A.-based ice-cream sandwich company with food trucks in L.A., New York, and Dallas, understands my need to move beyond the old-school sandwich. "Start by mixing a pinch of salt into store-bought ice cream to bring out the flavor of both the cookie and the ice cream," Case says. "Or spike the ice cream with a little alcohol." (Cointreau or amaretto are especially delicious here.) Finish it off by rolling the sides in something delicious. "Crushed hard cookie crumbs are always great and sprinkles are fun, colorful, and look cute," Case says.

Most important? Don't limit yourself to those smooshy cookies—the food editors in the Epicurious test kitchen certainly didn't. 

[#video: /videos/55d206f754b469aa41d13f77]|||
|||

Here are 7 seriously awesome combinations we came up with that break the mold (or the wrapper?):

##The Dog'wich##
*Hot dog bun + coconut ice cream + mangos + salted peanuts*

This [Thai-style ice cream combo](http://www.saveur.com/article/Recipes/Pok-Pok) will make you think of hot dog buns in a strange, but delicious way. The soft, mild bread combines perfectly with creamy coconut ice cream. Add diced mangoes and chopped roasted, salted peanuts and it's basically like you took a trip to Thailand, but not.

##The Biscuit'wich##
*Biscuit + peach ice cream + peach jam*

Upgrade classic [shortcake](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/whiskeyed-peach-shortcakes-56389789) by swiping a split biscuit with a layer of peach jam before filling it with a big ol' scoop of ice cream. You may need a spoon, a fork, and a knife to eat it. You won't care.

##The Brownie'wich##
*Brownies + mint chocolate chip ice cream*

We bet that [brownies](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/fudgy-double-chocolate-brownies-56389363) have always felt a little hostile towards cookies for having all the ice cream sandwich fun—now it's payback time.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce22e86a622aab4ea641b7]||||||

+++

##The Donut'Wich##
*Cinnamon-sugar cake donut + coffee ice cream + chocolate covered espresso beans*

We wouldn't blame you if you ate this sweet twist on the classic morning combination for breakfast. Hey, if the [Sicilians eat ice cream for breakfast](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/sicilian-ice-cream-sandwiches-239168), why can't you?

##The Croissant'wich##
*Croissant + strawberry ice cream + strawberry jam*

A flaky, buttery croissant on its own is all well and good. But when you think about it, those airy pockets are meant to be filled with ice cream. Slather a layer of strawberry jam on the split pastry before piling in the ice cream just for good measure. 

##The PB'wich##
*Peanut butter cookies + black raspberry ice cream + salted peanuts*

A PB&J sandwich meets an ice cream sandwich and they live happily ever after. After smooshing the [cookies](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/peanut-butter-cookies-367212) with ice cream, roll the sides in chopped roasted, salted peanuts to add just a little crunch in every bite.

##The Waffle'wich##
*Waffles + butter pecan ice cream*

Whether you use frozen waffles from the store or save a few after [whipping up a batch](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/raised-waffles-40050) over the weekend, you will want to spread them with caramel-scented butter pecan. Tuck some sliced strawberries inside and roll the sides in chopped pecans, too. Because you can.

section3List.hed: How to Recreate Your Favorite Ice Cream Truck Treats
section3List.dek: No need to flag down the neighborhood ice cream truck.
section3List.promoHed: How to Make DIY Ice Cream Truck Treats
section3List.body:
We all know what it [sounds like](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eBlyC9bJacs). 

You can hear coming down the block. 

Of course, I'm talking about the ice cream truck. An audible beacon of happiness during my childhood. A mobile dispensary of all things creamy, sugary, and iconically summer. As a kid, I'd chase after these treats with a fervor that was unmatched by my love of pizza, burgers, or pretty much anything else. 

But go back and try any of these treats today and, well, they don't quite match up to the memories of yesteryear. They can hang out for way too long at the bottom of a reach-in freezer, slowly growing a thick winter pelt of freezer burn. In an age of high-end ice cream parlors and premium gelato at the supermarket, these mass-market treats just don't quite cut it. 

So, I thought, why don't we make our own?

[#video: /videos/55d4eb0054b469aa41d147e0]||||||

####Ice Cream Tacos with Chocolate and Peanuts#### 
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce18404b06801538805d49]||||||

+++

[The Choco Taco](http://www.klondikebar.com/default.aspx?gclid=Cj0KEQjw0tCuBRDIjJ_Mlb6zzpQBEiQAyjCoBk-8rRRaeE1cIEBqguzn_l4HpSnhszrsBZYC_82_YGsaAjAO8P8HAQ&gclsrc=aw.ds#Choco) is genius on paper—a taco-shaped waffle cone filled with fudge-swirled ice cream, dipped in chocolate, and covered in peanuts. The biggest challenge was that shell, shaped like a hard taco but tasting like a waffle cone. There are [methods online](http://www.seriouseats.com/recipes/2009/02/how-to-make-a-choco-taco-from-scratch.html) that call for making homemade crêpes, but we there had to be something simpler then that. The Test Kitchen's first attempt used hard-shell corn taco shells, which ended up tasting a bit too much like, well, corn. 

And then we cracked the code: Use store-bought waffle ice cream bowls instead. If you brush them with maple syrup and microwave for 30 seconds, the waffle bowls turn temporarily malleable. Act quickly, folding the now-limp shell into taco formation, then watch it magically harden into a vanilla ice cream-worthy vehicle. All that's left is to dip the thing in a combination of chocolate and coconut oil (aka ["magic shell"](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes-menus/how-to-make-your-own-chocolate-shell-with-just-two-ingredients-article)), along with some peanuts for that iconic crunch.

[#recipe: /recipes/55d4bdcf63b1ba1b5534b038]|||
Ice Cream Tacos With Chocolate and Peanuts
|||

####Strawberry Shortcake Ice Cream Bars####
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce18424b06801538805d55]||||||

+++

The original [strawberry shortcake bars](https://www.drumstick.com/nestle/bars-strawberry-shortcake.aspx) are great and all, but I could never tell you whatever, *exactly*, they're made of—vanilla, strawberry, and, er, crunchy stuff? A quick Google search reveals they're comprised of "artificially flavored creamy vanilla," a "strawberry center," and "an irresistible strawberry shortcake crumb coating." Luckily, I can tell you exactly what we put in [our DIY version](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/strawberry-shortcake-ice-cream-bars-56389962). It all starts by piling softened strawberry ice cream into a popsicle mold. While that's in the freezer, create a crumb topping by crushing up store-bought [freeze-dried strawberries](http://www.amazon.com/Natures-All-Foods-Freeze-Dried-Strawberries/dp/B005M4G4LI) and sugar cookies. 

As soon as the strawberry pops are hardened, remove them from the molds, and roll them in the berry crumbs. Repeat as often as required.

[#recipe: /recipes/55d4bd1b54b469aa41d144e8]|||
Strawberry Shortcake Ice Cream Bars
|||

####Chocolate-Dipped Ice Cream Cones with Peanuts#### 
+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce18414b06801538805d4d]||||||

+++

[The Drumstick](https://www.drumstick.com/flavors/) was the simplest of all to recreate in our Test Kitchen. Start by drizzling the same chocolate-coconut oil mixture as the chocolate taco into a store-bought sugar cone, rotating it in your hands to completely coat the inside. After the inside is safely hardened, press a scoop of vanilla ice cream on top, dip the ice cream into the remaining "magic shell" mixture, and finish with a sprinkle of peanuts.

And there you have it. Truck treats without the chase. 

[#recipe: /recipes/55d4be5263b1ba1b5534b046]|||
Chocolate-Dipped Ice Cream Cones With Peanuts
|||

section1List.hed: How to Make Ice Cream Instantly
section1List.dek: You've had [ice cream sandwiches](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/7-new-ways-to-make-ice-cream-sandwiches-article). Now try sandwich ice cream.
section1List.seoTitle: How to Make Three-Ingredient Vegan Ice Cream Instantly
section1List.seoDescription: Using only three ingredients and a food processor for this vegan ice cream.
section1List.socialTitle: How to Make Instant Ice Cream Even Better
section1List.socialDescription: Hint: It involves peanut butter and jelly.
section1List.body:
If I told you that ice cream can be made in mere minutes in a food processor, and it will actually be kind of good for you, would you believe me? 

Yeah, I wouldn't believe me either. Luckily, nobody has to take my word for it—last year, food blogs erupted with [the idea of a two-ingredient ice cream](http://sharedappetite.com/recipes/2-ingredient-paleo-nutella-banana-ice-cream/), a semi-frozen concoction that's dangerously easy to make and has a texture just like soft serve. To make it, you take frozen bananas and blend them with a nut butter. That's it—you just grab a spoon and eat.

[#article: /articles/551d5174e7851a541a30c95b]||||||

It's an idea that's almost too perfect—so easy and streamlined that it seemed like it couldn't possibly be improved upon. But with the help of the Epicurious food team, I believe I did just that.

I started by taking [Reginald’s White Chocolate Macadamia](http://reginaldshomemade.com/products/white-chocolate-macadamia-peanut-butter), a natural peanut butter from [our peanut butter tasting](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/best-creamy-peanut-butters-in-america-article) and blending it with some frozen bananas. Not bad, but not ice cream. And not very sweet, either, thanks to the natural-style peanut butter.

For the next test, the test kitchen pulled one of the mass-market peanut butters [from our taste test](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/best-creamy-peanut-butters-in-america-article) that ranked very high in sweetness. This peanut butter's composition was also creamier and fluffier than Reginald's, which the food team thought would pull the "ice cream" together better. It all worked—until the aftertaste, which was still bland and flat. Turns out, two-ingredient ice cream tastes a bit, well, two-dimensional.

Roasting the bananas seemed like a way to add depth, but that flavor came at a cost. The roasting ended up drying out the bananas, which made the texture of the ice cream more like a cool marshmallow than a frozen dessert.

A little magic from assistant food editor Katherine Sacks changed everything. While testing the ice creams one day, she was struck by inspiration. “I saw grape jelly out of the corner of my eye and decided to add that,” Katherine said. The result was a creamy, frosty take on (you guessed it) the classic PB&J—and a fruity and tart fix to an otherwise flat-tasting frozen dessert. 

This is a dessert that’s best eaten as soon as it’s ready. If you want to make it for a dinner party, freeze the banana chunks while setting up for dinner—come dessert time, just pull out the food processor and “make ice cream” in front of your guests’ eyes in just a couple minutes.

Just like magic. Vegan, peanut-buttery magic.

[#recipe: /recipes/55ccb8876a622aab4ea63b35]||||||

fields.title: Peanut Butter Jelly and Banana Ice Cream
fields.credit: Photo by Chelsea Kyle, Prop Styling by Alex Brannian, Food Styling by Michelle Gatton

section1List.hed: How to Thaw Rock Hard Ice Cream and Make It Instantly Smooth
section1List.dek: Hint: It doesn't involve the microwave.
section1List.promoHed: How to Turn Rock-Hard Ice Cream Instantly Smooth
section1List.body:
Here's the scene: you decide to throw a last-minute dinner party, and you're totally prepped and organized. (You've probably made lists. A lot of lists.) Things go without a hitch, and soon it's time for dessert. So you pull out a pint of ice cream, planning to serve it alongside some crushed cookies and smoked nuts ([#Dadstyle](http://www.epicurious.com/expert-advice/fathers-day-dessert-recipe-article)).

[#article: /articles/557762d274cbe9ed7c209ae7]||||||

But that's when all your careful planning hits a snag. Your scooper hits a substance that resembles just-poured concrete rather than ice cream. You strain, waving aside offers of assistance as you smile. "It's fine," you say. "Just a little cold is all." But the ice cream is not merely cold. It has, somehow, become one with the Earth's polar ice cap. And even if you took a power drill to it and busted it up into pieces, it wouldn't matter—no one wants to eat frosty shards of dairy. Letting it sit out to defrost for a few minutes isn't a solution, either. It only results in a melty perimeter, leaving the icy core untouched.

What to do? Do what I did when I worked in the pastry kitchen at fine-dining restaurants (which just happens to be the same thing folks at mix-in places like [Cold Stone Creamery](https://www.coldstonecreamery.com/) and [Marble Slab](http://www.marbleslab.com/Default.aspx) do): Mash up that ice cream.

1. Take your ice cream out of the freezer. Let it soften for a few minutes, but no more than 5—you want to thaw it just long enough to extricate it out of the container.

2. Place the ice cream into the bowl of a stand mixer* fit with the paddle attachment. Mix on medium until the ice cream is smooth and creamy. Be careful not to mix too long—it *will* get soupy. 

3. Instantly forget about that icy mess from moments before and serve that silky smooth ice cream stat.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce23764b06801538805d96]||||||

+++

##One more thing...##
Hold on. Your ice cream is already in the mixing bowl. So why not, you know, mix something into it? Take a cue from Cold Stone and blend in anything you'd try as a topping for ice cream—crushed cookies, chopped fresh fruit or berries, toasted nuts, candy, chocolate—even crushed sugar cones.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce23756a622aab4ea641c5]||||||

+++

*Don't have a stand mixer? You can also break up the hard ice cream into pieces in a large bowl, using a knife if you need to, and then mash the ice cream until smooth with a potato masher. Once smooth, stir in the toppings with a heavy-duty wooden spoon. Just keep in mind that this method will take a bit longer, so the ice cream may get too soft, and you'll want to stick it back in the freezer for 10 minutes or so before serving.

section1List.seoDescription: Tips on fixing rock-hard ice cream at home.
section1List.socialTitle: How to Turn Your Ice Cream Instantly Smooth

section1List.hed: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section1List.dek: This crunchy, cocoa-flavored ice-cream topping might not technically be magical, but it is amazingly easy.
section1List.promoHed: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section1List.seoTitle: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section1List.socialTitle: How to Make Your Own Chocolate Shell with Just Two Ingredients
section1List.body:
Growing up, few things were greater than seeing a bottle of Magic Shell at a birthday party next to the cake and ice cream.

For the unfamiliar, this syrupy concoction that hardens into a shell was a staple at every gathering that involved a DIY ice cream bar. It comes in various flavors (like caramel and even root beer) but I think we can all agree that chocolate fudge was the real deal.

I personally liked to use a 2:1 ratio of shell to ice cream when I was a kid. Sometimes I would just freeze a plate, pour Magic Shell all over it, and scrape away with a fork. My chocoholic tendencies continued well into adulthood, which is why I was delighted to discover that this addictive coating, believe it or not, is hardly "magic." You can even make it yourself with just two ingredients, and it's still every bit as great when you're older. Besides adding it to sundaes, you can also make your own chocolate covered ice cream bars or dip fruits in it. Here how it's done:

__For 1 cup of chocolate shell, you'll need:__

2 cups good quality chocolate, finely chopped

1/4 cup refined coconut oil

__Directions:__

1. Add the chocolate to a microwave-safe bowl or container along with the coconut oil.

2. Microwave, in 30 second intervals, until completely melted.

3. Pour it over ice cream and watch the magic happen (allow 30 seconds before you try to crack it. You will know it's ready when the shell turns from glossy to matte). Note: If the chocolate shell re-hardens as you use it, you can just microwave it again (briefly) until liquidy.

__Here are some things we want to smother or dip in homemade chocolate shell:__

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4234e6529d92b2c0099bf]|||
Cherry-Bourbon Ice Cream
|||

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4244619925f464b37a1a3]|||
Apricot Rice Pudding Pops
|||

[#recipe: /recipes/54a421586529d92b2c008855]|||
Peanut Butter Ice Cream with a Hard Chocolate Shell
|||

section1List.hed: 10 Things You Didn't Know You Could Do With Store-Bought Vanilla Ice Cream
section1List.dek: Hot fudge and a maraschino cherry? Strictly 101.
section1List.promoHed: How to Turn Store-Bought Vanilla Ice Cream Into 10 New Treats
section1List.body:
A pint of vanilla ice cream seems like the most, well, *vanilla* thing in the world. Sure, it's always great scooped over [warm pie](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/the-easiest-peach-raspberry-pie-with-press-in-crust-56389627), or drizzled with [hot fudge](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/hot-fudge-sauce-109144). 

But like many other superheroes, vanilla hides its true potential in plain sight. The secret power of that store-bought staple is its ability to quickly transform into a completely new identity. Diabolical? No, just delicious. 

####1. Ice Pops####
Soften your vanilla ice cream a bit and scoop it into ice pop molds to freeze into ice cream treats on sticks. Stir in fruit, nuts, or chocolate before freezing, or dip them in melted chocolate after freezing to make a hard shell. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42e3f6529d92b2c012164]||||||


####2. Make Ice Cream Sandwiches####
Ice cream cookie sandwiches are classic, but think outside the cookie jar for even more exciting sandwiches. Want inspiration? [We've got 7 new ways to make ice cream sandwiches.](https://epicurious.conde.io/expert-advice/7-new-ways-to-make-ice-cream-sandwiches-article) 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55ce22e84b06801538805d84]||||||

+++

####3. Make Pie####
Layer your vanilla ice cream into a pie crust with your favorite sauce (or fruit or chocolate) and freeze it until firm. Slice and serve like a pie—voilà! 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42cfd19925f464b380b50]||||||


####4. Make Cake####
Store-bought or homemade cake can become ice cream cake when spread with softened ice cream between layers and frozen. Once you see how easy it is, all your summer birthday cakes will become ice cream cakes. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4230b6529d92b2c0097ae]||||||


####5. Cover it in meringue####
The ultimate in over-the-top presentation: Baked Alaska. Cover cake and ice cream in piles of meringue and set the whole thing on fire—showy, yes, but also delicious. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a431ee6529d92b2c014fe8]||||||

####6. Turn it into a new flavor ####
If you find yourself wishing you had a different flavor of ice cream but all you have is vanilla, toss that ice cream in your stand mixer with something to flavor it and beat until incorporated: fresh berries, coffee, peanut butter, chocolate sauce, crushed candy, cookies.... you choose. [Here's how to do it.](https://epicurious.conde.io/expert-advice/how-to-thaw-rock-hard-ice-cream-and-make-it-instantly-smooth-article) 

####7. Melt it into sauce####
That thick and creamy sweet sauce on your dessert plate last time you ate out at a classic French restaurant was probably *crème anglaise*. That sauce also happens to be the custard base for classic ice cream. So if you want that sauce without having to actually, you know, *make* that sauce, just melt some vanilla ice cream, whisk it a bit until foamy, and serve it drizzled over your cake, custard, or fresh fruit. Just make sure you're using a vanilla ice cream with eggs as one of the ingredients.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/54b2f0c43edeef84363b416d]||||||

+++


####8. Melt it to make French toast####
Want extra decadent, vanilla-scented French toast? Use melted vanilla ice cream instead of eggs and milk. Make sure you're using ice cream made with eggs for this one too, and whisk in an extra egg to help thicken it. 

####9. Melt it and use it in the batter of baked goods####
When you start thinking of melted ice cream as an instant custard base, it opens up a whole slew of baking possibilities. Like how about some Key Lime pie? 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a421b819925f464b378929]||||||

####10. Shake it up####
Take your favorite pint of vanilla ice cream and some fresh fruit and whizz it up in the blender for an easy seasonal milkshake that you could *almost* justify having for breakfast. 

[#recipe: /recipes/54a432ee6529d92b2c015cdb]||||||

section1List.seoDescription: 10 new frozen treats you can make with store-bought vanilla ice cream.
section1List.socialTitle: 10 Things You Didn't Know You Could Make With Store-Bought Vanilla Ice Cream
section1List.socialDescription: That container of ice cream in your freezer just got a lot more exciting.
